instructions.text: Check for responsiveness: Shake the victim gently and shout, "Are you okay?"
Call for help: If the victim is unresponsive, call for emergency medical services (EMS) or ask someone nearby to do so.
Open the airway: Tilt the victim's head back gently and lift the chin to open their airway.
Check for breathing: Look, listen, and feel for breaths. If the victim is not breathing or is only gasping, begin CPR.

Perform chest compressions: Place the heel of one hand on the center of the victim's chest and the other hand on top of the first. Push down hard and fast, aiming for a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute.
Give rescue breaths: Pinch the victim's nose closed and give two full breaths into their mouth, making sure the chest rises with each breath.
Continue CPR: Alternate between chest compressions and rescue breaths, continuing until help arrives or the victim starts to breathe on their own.
Call emergency services immediately, if not already done.
Locate the nearest AED and bring it to the person in need.
Turn on the AED and follow the voice prompts.
Remove any clothing or jewelry that may interfere with the AED pads.
Attach the AED pads to the person's bare chest as indicated on the pads.
Stand clear and let the AED analyze the person's heart rhythm.
If a shock is advised, make sure no one is touching the person and press the shock button as directed.
Immediately begin CPR after the shock is delivered, as instructed by the AED or emergency services.
Stand behind the person and wrap your arms around their waist.
Make a fist with one hand and place it just above the person's belly button.
Grasp your fist with your other hand and press inward and upward into the person's abdomen with a quick upward thrust.
Repeat thrusts until the object blocking the person's airway is dislodged or they become unconscious.
Clean your hands with soap and water or use hand sanitizer.
Apply pressure with a clean cloth or bandage to stop any bleeding.
Clean the wound with mild soap and water or saline solution.
Gently pat the wound dry with a clean cloth.
Apply an antibiotic ointment to the wound.
Cover the wound with a sterile bandage or dressing.
Remove the source of heat or electricity.
Cool the burn with cool running water for at least 10-20 minutes.
Cover the burn with a sterile, non-adhesive dressing or clean cloth.
Elevate the affected area if possible.
Do not apply ice, ointments, or butter to the burn.
Seek medical attention if the burn is severe or covers a large area of the body.
Call for emergency medical services.
Have the person lie down and elevate their legs unless it causes pain or discomfort.
Cover the person with a blanket to keep them warm.
Monitor their breathing, pulse, and level of consciousness.
Do not give the person anything to eat or drink.
Stay with the person and reassure them until medical help arrives.
Remove the source of the allergen if possible.
Call for emergency medical services.
Administer an epinephrine auto-injector if the person has one and is able to use it.
Have the person lie down and elevate their legs.
Monitor their breathing, pulse, and level of consciousness.
If the person is vomiting, turn them on their side to prevent choking.
Do not give the person anything to eat or drink.
Stay with the person and reassure them until medical help arrives.
Move the person to a cooler place.
Loosen or remove any tight clothing.
Cool the person down with cold compresses or by immersing them in cool water.
Fan the person to help with evaporation.
Offer the person fluids, such as water or a sports drink, but avoid alcohol or caffeine.
Monitor their temperature and continue cooling efforts until their temperature drops to 101°F (38.3°C).
Seek medical attention immediately if the person's condition does not improve or worsens.
Call the poison control center or emergency services immediately.
Provide the name of the poison if known, the age and weight of the person affected, and any symptoms they may be experiencing.
Do not give the person anything to eat or drink unless instructed to do so by medical professionals.
If the poison was inhaled, move the person to fresh air immediately.
If the poison was ingested and the person is conscious, rinse their mouth with water and give them a small amount of water to drink.
If the person is unconscious, not breathing, or having seizures, begin CPR or first aid as necessary while waiting for medical professionals to arrive.
Follow any additional instructions provided by the poison control center or emergency services.
